review_title: Great place to work, but no room to grow
pros:
- Great products and services that are easy to be passionate about
- Positive, upbeat atmosphere
- Great training and benefits
cons: - promotions are very hard to get, no one leaves

pros:
- Inclusive culture living by what they call the “credo”. The old one was better, but you can google that. (ie. you will not be discriminated for the colour of your skin, your sex, gender identity, tattoos, piercings, disabilities, etc).

- Decent pay for a retail store no matter what position.

- Internal position growth opportunities are available and a lot of it revolves around personal development rather than just numbers even if numbers are a factor.

- Benefits are incredible as a part-timer… almost on-par with full-time employees.

- Great Employee discounts and family friend discounts.

- You can participate in ESPP (Employee Stock Purchase Program) and even have GRSP matching.

All-in-all, why would you want to leave with all the great benefits?
cons:
- They don’t exactly value seniority. If you’re interested in a position, you might get overlooked by newer, fresher, younger talent. If you’re okay with staying in the same position for a while, make sure you apply for the right one… however, you may need to work your way up from the bottom. If you don’t like sales and want to work at the Genius Bar, too bad. You’ll most likely have to start out as a Product Zone Specialist for a few years.

- During the pandemic they weren’t hiring externally, so if someone sought internal movement, they’ll look for the weakest link to let go of while giving very few chances or opportunities to correct or improve.

- They don’t quite take HR scenarios that seriously. As someone who was quite bullied by my peers for the last few years of my employment, management and HR didn’t take it seriously and were pretty dismissive. It almost feels sociopathic to know that the company hides behind the facade know is “empathy” to mask their true intent.

- Managers change often, so your transition into the next role may get stunted. Be prepared to log in your “exchange journal” every single little bit of success and every challenge and growth opportunity you have so that the next manager you talk to about the next promotion can quickly skim through it before they tell you what you need to work on to get into the next role… which was probably very different from what the last manager said.

- Be prepared to have your vacation/RTO request denied and be prepared to almost always work weekends. Honestly, be prepared to dedicate most of your daily life to Apple Retail. You will probably be there more than home or anywhere else with whatever remaining “free time” you have available to you.

Apple likes to talk a big game about caring about equity, but they don't. In fact, many of their support orgs practice blatant discrimination. For example. some folks are permitted to work remotely from home, while others are told it's not possible. I am an employee who was with Apple for over a decade, and routinely got stellar performance reviews. I was also promoted multiple times. I also have a chronic serious health condition, where I was told despite the pandemic I would not be able work remotely once things resumed in-office. Meanwhile, other folks within the org were permitted to move to other cities and work remotely, for seemingly lesser reasons. 

Apple is not the forward-thinking, kindly company they portray themselves to be. In addition, someone within my org several years ago disclosed confidential personal information related to my health to an outside party at another company, and no action was taken against this employee. Apple needs to seriously consider the HR implications related to this illegal behavior.

I have since left for a better, more inclusive company that values remote work and equitable solutions for all employees, without discriminating. I leave this review to warn others of the reality of working at Apple, and also because I still believe the company has some great people there. Maybe they need to take a hard, long look at their behaviors to improve it.
